frameDefinitions: This frame contains adjectives and nouns that describe the truth or sincerity of communication.
The existence of a State_of_affairs is sufficient reason for taking an Action .
In this frame, which is a  part of the Trial sequence, a Judge gives a Finding with respect to the Charges against the Defendant in a particular Case.
An Accused individual is deemed by a (usually implicit)
This frame covers descriptions of an entire human body, viewed as a gestalt (as opposed to descriptions based on salient body parts).
A particular piece of Information is evaluated for its accuracy.
frameExamples: Evelyn was <t>candid</t> with me about the party.
The underwater sequences <t>warrant</t> the price of the admission alone.
He was <t>convicted</t> of fraud by Judge Judy.
I am <t>innocent</t> of this crime and so is James Griffiths .
Is your reputation at risk due to <t>incorrect</t> information?
listRoleDefinitions: The <fen>Speaker</fen> produces the <fen>Message</fen>, the truth or sincerity of which is at issue. It is normally expressed as the External Argument of predicative uses of the <t>target</t> word, or as the Nominal Head of prenominal uses.

<fen>Message</fen> is the communicative content whose truth or sincerity is at issue. This role does not normally co-occur with the other FEs in this frame. When it does occur, it is normally the External Argument of a predicative use of the <t>Target</t> word, or the modified Nominal Head in a prenominal use.

The <fen>Topic</fen> is the subject matter to which the <fen>Message</fen> pertains. It often occurs without the <fen>Message</fen> role in predicative uses of the <t>target</t> word. It is normally expressed as a PP Complement headed by 'about'.
<fen>Medium</fen> is the physical or abstract setting in which the <fen>Message</fen> is conveyed.
An Eventuality or an Entity that is taken to constitute sufficient reason for taking another <fen>Action</fen>.
An <fen>Action</fen> that is taken to be justifiable given the <fen>State_of_Affairs</fen>.
The <fen>Judge</fen> (which may be the jury, judge, magistrate or court) decides on the <fen>Finding</fen>.
This role identifies the outcome of the <fen>Judge</fen>'s deliberation or consideration. Many LUs in this frame incorporate this FE.
The person who stands accused of a crime and is subject to the verdict.
This role refers to the <fen>Charges</fen> with respect to which the verdict is being given.
The <fen>Case</fen> on which the verdict is being given.
When the event occurs.
Where the event takes place.
This is the person who is accused of a  <fen>Misdeed</fen>.
The wrongful act which  the <fen>Accused</fen> was purportedly involved in.
This role identifies the individual (or individuals) being described.
This role identifies the <fen>Figure</fen> or form being described by the target.
The <fen>Information</fen> matches or does not match the facts of the world.
The <fen>Source</fen> is the agent who holds the correct/incorrect information.
The event which communicates the <fen>Information</fen>.
The Topic about which the Source has accurate information.
The <fen>Time</fen> at which the <fen>Information</fen> or the <fen>Source</fen> is correct.
listRoleExamples: Evelyn made some candid remarks <fex>in French</fex>.
<fex>A heavy contact to the opponent 's face</fex> may not merit just a verbal warning
<fex>Frank Quattrone</fex> is found guilty of obstructing federal investigations
Cambridge woman says she's innocent <fex>of fraud</fex>.

Look Me In The Eye: My Life With Asperger's
